chapter_title: The modern age in Europe (A) Renaissance

sections.title: CAUSES OF RENAISSANCE
sections.content_md: The term **Renaissance** means rebirth or revival. It stands for a complex transitional movement in Europe between medieval and modern times beginning in the 14th century in Italy and lasting into the 17th century. It marked the revival of the freedom to think and act without being controlled by any external agency. It was also a revival of the study of the ancient Greek and Roman classics. One of the remarkable changes was the disintegration of the feudal system in Europe which ushered in a new social and economic order, marking the beginning of the modern era.

sections.title: CAPTURE OF CONSTANTINOPLE
sections.content_md: **Constantinople** was the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire and a centre of Greek and Roman cultures, holding valuable manuscripts of Greek and Roman writers. When Constantinople fell into the hands of the **Turks in 1453**, many Greek and Roman scholars were forced to shift to Rome and other parts of Europe with their manuscripts. Rome then became the centre of Greek culture. These scholars, who were men of liberal outlook, humanism and logical thinking, spread their new spirit and ideas wherever they went. They revived the interest of the people in the study of Greek philosophy, science, art and literature. The revival of the learning of Greek classics paved the way for the Renaissance.

sections.title: DECLINE OF FEUDALISM
sections.content_md:
**Feudalism** was a system where medieval European society was organised on the basis of land tenure. People, from the King down to the lowest landowners, were bound together by obligation and defence.

*   The **King** gave estates to his lords, known as **Dukes** and **Earls**.
*   The **Lords** distributed land to lesser lords or **Barons**, who provided military support.
*   Dukes and Earls owed allegiance to the King, while Barons owed allegiance to the Dukes and Earls.
*   **Knights** formed the lower category of feudal lords.
*   The feudal lords gave land to peasants for cultivation.

[Image: Feudal Structure]

The society had a graded organisation with little chance for social mobility and progress, and it was opposed to freedom and equality of rights. The **decline of feudalism in the 13th and 14th centuries** provided an impetus to free thinking. The resulting peace and freedom favoured the growth of New Learning, leading to new developments in art, literature, philosophy, and science, which contributed to the rise of the Renaissance.

sections.title: NEW TRADE ROUTES
sections.content_md:
[Image: Christopher Columbus]
[Image: Ferdinand Magellan]

The navigators of Portugal and Spain were important in geographical explorations and discovering new trade routes. After the fall of Constantinople to the Turks in 1453, the trade routes between the West and the East were closed. This created a need for European traders and navigators to discover new sea routes.

*   **Prince Henry**, the Navigator of Portugal, discovered a sea route to Africa.
*   **Bartholomew Diaz** reached the Cape of Good Hope at the southernmost point of Africa.
*   **Columbus** discovered America in 1492.
*   In 1498, **Vasco da Gama** sailed to India.
*   **Ferdinand Magellan** made a voyage around the world, reaching a vast ocean he called the Pacific Ocean.

These discoveries developed contact and a fusion of ideas between the East and West. The new trade routes encouraged trade, created a spirit of adventure, and broadened the mental horizon.

sections.title: SPIRIT OF ENQUIRY
sections.content_md: In the Medieval Age, human activities were controlled by the authority of the Pope and the Church, and independent thinking was not allowed. However, many scholars discarded medieval ideas and developed a **spirit of enquiry** and curiosity. They taught people to ask the 'Why' and 'How' of things, questioning the authority of the Church and seeking a transition from faith to reason, observation, and experimentation.

sections.title: Role of Original Thinkers
sections.content_md: During the Medieval Age, the Church discouraged original thinking, demanding faith in its dogmas. However, bold and independent thinkers criticised the Church and encouraged people to develop their own thinking. Thinkers like **Roger Bacon**, **Abelard**, and **Thomas Aquinas** revolutionised the thought process, laying stress on reasoning. These original thinkers are known as the **forerunners of Renaissance**.

sections.title: Crusades
sections.content_md:
[Image: Sixteenth century ship]

The **Crusades** were religious expeditionary wars with the goal of restoring the Church's access to holy places in and near Jerusalem. They brought the people of Europe into direct contact with the people of Asia, introducing ideas from the East to Western Europe. This widened their outlook on life, and people began to rely on reason rather than on blind faith.

sections.title: Development of Science
sections.content_md:
In the age of faith, science had little scope. However, some medieval scholars showed a scientific attitude and encouraged students to observe nature, leading to new inventions and discoveries. The development of science created a spirit of enquiry and scientific temper.

*   **Roger Bacon** contemplated the use of horseless carriages and flying machines.
*   **Copernicus** proved that the earth moves round the sun.
*   **Galileo** invented the telescope.

These inventions broadened the mental outlook of the people and ended old beliefs and traditions.

sections.title: INVENTION OF THE PRINTING PRESS
sections.content_md:
[Image: Printing Press]

The first printing press was set up in Germany by **Gutenberg** in the middle of the 15th century. Later, **Caxton** introduced it in England.

The invention made it possible to produce books in large numbers. The Bible and other religious and classical books were printed and made available across Europe. The printing press spread knowledge widely, as scholars found printed books easier to read than hand-written manuscripts. In the Middle Ages, books were few and beyond the reach of ordinary people. The Printing Press enabled the multiplication and distribution of books, influencing people's attitudes to life and bringing about a new awakening in Europe.

sections.title: PRINCIPLES OF RENAISSANCE
sections.content_md: The Renaissance was not a sudden development but was based on certain beliefs and features that affected all aspects of life, including common people, aristocrats, kings, and Popes.

sections.title: Humanism
sections.content_md:
[Image: Renaissance Paintings]

**Humanism** was the most remarkable phenomenon of Renaissance, arising from the spread of education. The word 'humanism' is derived from the Latin words '**Studia humanitatis**' or 'the studies of mankind'. It represented a decisive shift in concern for humans as distinct from divine matters. **Humanism** extolled man and stressed his essential dignity. It was centred on man's earthly joys and sorrows, opposing religious asceticism. It defended man's right to pleasure and the satisfaction of earthly desires. Humanists looked to ancient classics from thinkers like **Plato, Virgil, Aristotle, Cicero, and Quintilianus** for ideas.

*Note: In this Chapter, following traditional conventions, man is used to refer to humankind as an entity.*

sections.title: Glorification of Human Form
sections.content_md: Renaissance scholars and artists glorified the human body. Their work was permeated with the belief that a man with an active mind and body could know and control the world, perform miracles, and shape his own happiness. This spirit of humanism was expressed in the new art and literature. Renaissance artists, though often taking subjects from the Bible, portrayed the human form in all its earthly beauty and vigour.

sections.title: Spirit of Enquiry
sections.content_md: The Renaissance humanists believed in the limitless potential of man but also valued the past. The **spirit of enquiry** extended from scientific investigation of nature to explorations and expeditions, probing every realm of knowledge. It became a principal cause of the Renaissance.

sections.title: Beginning of Renaissance
sections.content_md:
The Renaissance first began in Italy and spread from there to other parts of the world for the following reasons:

1.  **Italy was the seat of the glorious Roman Empire**, and all its historical remains and relics attracted numerous scholars and artists.
2.  Following the **Fall of Constantinople**, a large number of Greek scholars and thinkers migrated to Italy with their original manuscripts and art treasures. They instilled a spirit of enquiry and encouraged Italian artists and writers to produce masterpieces.
3.  The **enormous wealth** Italy accumulated from trade with the East contributed to the rise of Renaissance. The wealthy merchants of Italy patronised artists and literary figures, using their wealth to revive classical culture and literature.
4.  As a result of the **crusades and geographical explorations**, Italians came into contact with the East, which greatly broadened their vision and provided an impetus to Renaissance.

sections.title: IMPACT OF RENAISSANCE
sections.content_md: The Renaissance had a great impact on all aspects of life including art, literature, philosophy, science, and religion. The spirit of Renaissance led to significant new traits in art, thought, and literature.

sections.title: ART
sections.content_md: The Renaissance led to a rebirth of art. In medieval times, paintings and sculptures were tools for propagating religion, with even the colours being strictly regulated. Renaissance artists refused to follow medieval rules and traditions. They adopted new artistic methods like **frescoes** for wall pictures, **oil colours**, and **woodcuts**. They studied optics and geometry to develop perspective in their paintings and also studied human anatomy to understand the mechanics of gestures and expressions.

sections.title: PAINTING
sections.content_md:
Renaissance painters established very high standards, producing some of the greatest paintings of the time. They were able to express their talent without being restricted by the Church's rigid rules. They adopted a humanistic, secular approach and created highly artistic and life-like paintings.

Prominent painters of the Renaissance period include:
*   **Leonardo Da Vinci:** A great painter, sculptor, musician, and scientist. Apprenticed at around age 15 to the noted sculptor and painter **Andrea del Verrocchio** of Florence. Da Vinci's interests were vast, including nature, mechanics, anatomy, and architecture. He saw science and art as complementary and kept thousands of pages of notebooks with illustrations on painting, architecture, mechanics, and human anatomy. His famous paintings, **'The Virgin of the Rocks'**, **'The Last Supper'**, and **'Mona Lisa'**, are masterpieces that used new techniques to create a fine feeling of reality.
    [Image: Leonardo Da Vinci]
    [Image: Mona Lisa]
    [Image: The Last Supper by Leonardo da Vinci]
*   **Michelangelo:** A painter, sculptor, architect, and poet who concentrated on painting the human figure. He is famous for his paintings in the **Sistine Chapel** in the Vatican, which depict incidents and persons from the Old Testament. **'Last Judgement'** and **'The Fall of Man'** are among his most famous works.
*   **Raphael:** A great artist of the Florentine school. His most celebrated painting is **'Sistine Madonna'**. He worked for the Pope in Rome, decorating the Vatican and designing **St. Peter's Church**.
    [Image: St. Peter's Church, Rome]

sections.title: SCULPTURE
sections.content_md:
The revival of the study of antiquity greatly impacted sculpture. Some Renaissance artists copied Greek and Roman masterpieces, while others produced outstanding new works.

Outstanding sculptors of the period include:
*   **Donatello:** The first great sculptor of the Renaissance, known for the bronze statue of **David**, triumphant over the slain Goliath.
*   **Lorenzo Ghiberti:** A famous Italian sculptor who worked for 20 years to create two pairs of bronze doors for the Baptistery at Florence.
*   **Michelangelo:** Created the statue in Rome called **'Pieta'**, showing Mother Mary with the body of Jesus. He also made the huge statues of **David** and **Moses** in Florence.

[Image: Statue of Moses by Michelangelo]
[Image: Pieta]

Many sculptors in Italy worked for Popes or rich merchants. Later, they were invited to England, France, and Spain, spreading Renaissance art across Western Europe.

sections.title: LITERATURE
sections.content_md:
The most significant impact on literature was the use of **local languages** instead of Latin. The themes also changed from spiritual matters to a focus on man and his problems, a movement known as **Humanism**.

**Literature in Italy:**
*   **Machiavelli:** A great political writer, author of **'The Prince'**.
*   **Dante:** His epic poem **'Divine Comedy'** describes the state of the soul and reveals the religious and social life of the time.
*   **Petrarch:** A great scholar and writer, called **'the father of humanism'**. His sonnets and lyrics were popular.
*   **Boccaccio:** Wrote in prose; his work **'Decameron'** is a collection of 100 famous short stories.
*   Other writers included **Aristo** and **Tasso**.

**Literature in England:**
*   **Geoffrey Chaucer:** Heralded Renaissance literature in England and is regarded as the **'Father of English Poetry'**. **'The Canterbury Tales'** is his outstanding work.
*   **Thomas More:** Wrote **'Utopia'**, describing an imaginary island where the rich did not exploit the poor and society was free from blind faith and useless wars.
*   Other famous writers included **Francis Bacon** (essayist), **Ben Johnson**, and **Marlowe** (dramatists).
*   **Milton's** 'Paradise Lost' and **Edmund Spencer's** 'Faerie Queene' are other notable works.

[Image: William Shakespeare]
**William Shakespeare:**
An English poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist. He is often called England's national poet and the **'Bard of Avon'**. He wrote 38 plays, 154 sonnets, and other poems. 
*   **Early Plays:** Mostly historical dramas (e.g., *Richard II*, *Henry VI*, *Henry V*) and comedies (e.g., *A Midsummer Night's Dream*, *Much Ado About Nothing*, *As You Like It*, *Twelfth Night*).
*   **Tragedies (after 1600):** *Hamlet*, *King Lear*, *Othello*, and *Macbeth*.
Shakespeare's work transcends culture and history, appealing to universal human emotions and thoughts.

sections.title: SCIENCE
sections.content_md:
The Renaissance marked the beginning of modern science. Previously, all views, including scientific ones, had to be supported by the authority of the scriptures. Renaissance scientists believed that scientific views should be based on **observation and experimentation**. The methods of enquiry, questioning, observation, and experimentation are still used in scientific investigations today.

[Image: Nicolaus Copernicus]

*   **Nicolaus Copernicus:** A mathematician and astronomer who formulated a **heliocentric model** of the universe, placing the sun at the center rather than the earth. His model was published in his book **'De revolutionibus orbium celestium'** (On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres) just before his death in 1543, triggering the Copernican Revolution.
    **Copernicus's Heliocentric Theory:**
    *   There is no single center for all celestial circles or spheres.
    *   The center of the earth is not the center of the universe, but only of gravity and the lunar sphere.
    *   All spheres revolve around the sun as their midpoint; therefore, the sun is the center of the universe.
    *   The earth has more than one motion: turning on its axis and moving in a spherical orbit around the sun.
*   **John Kepler:** A German scientist who proved that planets move around the sun in **elliptical orbits**, not circles.
*   **Galileo:** An Italian scientist who invented the **telescope**.
*   **Sir Isaac Newton:** Discovered the **Law of Gravitation**.
*   **Medical Science:** **Vesalius** wrote a treatise on anatomy. **William Harvey**, an English physician, discovered the **circulation of blood**. **Paracelsus** showed the connection between medicine and chemistry. **Cordus** prepared ether. **Helmontt** discovered carbon dioxide.
*   **Other advances:** Arabs contributed **Algebra and numerals**. **Desargues** systematized Modern Geometry. **Stevin** advocated the decimal system for coins, weights, and measures.

sections.title: CONSEQUENCES OF RENAISSANCE
sections.content_md: The Renaissance had several significant consequences for Europe.

sections.title: Ded to the Reformation Movement in Europe
sections.content_md: Renaissance paved the way for the **Reformation** in England and Europe. People started viewing everything through questioning, observation, and experimentation. They became critical of rituals practiced by the Church and insisted on its reform. This led to the division of the Church into two sectsâ€”**Catholics** and **Protestants**.

sections.title: Development of Humanism
sections.content_md: In the Middle Ages, the primary study was spirituality and theology. Renaissance widened the outlook of people, creating an interest in man, his interests, his nature, and his life in this world. It developed **humanism** and encouraged the study of humanities.

sections.title: Development of Scientific Outlook
sections.content_md: Renaissance contributed to the development of a scientific attitude, encouraging people to accept things only if they appealed to reason. This scientific outlook was a setback to blind faith and encouraged new discoveries and inventions, contributing to the progress of human civilisation.

sections.title: Rise of Monarchical Form of Government
sections.content_md: Renaissance provided impetus to the evolution of a strong monarchical system of government in Europe. The decline of the authority of the Church and the feudal system strengthened the people's desire for peace, security, and political stability. They readily supported kings and enhanced the powers of monarchs.

sections.title: Development of Arts
sections.content_md: Renaissance led to new forms of paintings, sculpture, architecture, music, etc. It rendered valuable service to the growth of fine arts.

sections.title: Rise of the Middle Class
sections.content_md: In the Middle Ages, feudal lords controlled most of the territory and enjoyed comforts and luxuries. The new movement caused a setback for them. In their place, traders, soldiers, lawyers, and others belonging to the **Middle Class** began to make rapid progress.

sections.title: Rise and Growth of Nation States
sections.content_md: Renaissance led to feelings of nationality and the progress of national literature. This, in turn, led to the rise and growth of **nation states**.

sections.title: Consequences of Geographical Explorations
sections.content_md: Scientific inventions enabled people to explore new routes and distant lands. These geographical discoveries led to the establishment of trade between Europe and the East, which brought prosperity to Europe. They also paved the way for the **colonisation of Asia and Africa**. European countries began to export the resources of their colonies in America, Asia, and Africa to increase their power.
